result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Gregory Williams

records.addlTxt: Filed by Prosecutor. Date: December 27, 2022 at 2 pm, Br 3, before Honorable Louis Molepske Jr
Initial Appearance set for 12/19/22 @ 2:00 p.m. in Br 2

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt: Initial Appearance set for 10/24/22 @ 1:15 p.m. in Br 3

Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
Do not associate with any persons possessing or consuming illegal controlled substances.

1:52 PM Defendant Gregory Williams appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Kelly A Cassidy in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Attorney Taylor Soule  appears on behalf of the defendant.

Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Cassidy states facts for anticipated charges of Possession w/Intent to Deliver Narcotic drugs. 
Attorney for the defendant does not have anything to state about the facts of the case.
Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.
Court informs defendant of right to an attorney and/or public defender.
Defendant   is  eligible for public defender representation.
Court questions defendant. 
State requests a cash bond with conditions as stated. 
Attorney for the defendant objects to cash bond and states reasons on the record.
Hearing scheduled for October 24, 2022 at 01:15 pm.
